did.unittitle: Wagner Free Institute of Science director's files and business records

bioghist.p: Incorporated by William Wagner in 1855, the Wagner Free Institute is a natural history museum and educational institution in Philadelphia that is dedicated to providing free public education in the sciences. William Wagner originally offered free lectures and classes in his home and at Spring Garden Hall. He later constructed an Institute building, which opened to the public in 1865. Since 1891, the specimen collections have been displayed according to Darwinian principles of evolution, the organizational scheme selected by renowned biologist Joseph Leidy during his tenure as head of the Institute's scientific and educational programs in the late 19th century. During the period of time covered by these records, the director of the Wagner Free Institute of Science oversaw the daily running of the Institute's educational, library, and museum activities. The director reported to the Board of Trustees, and that body made decisions about the Institute's financial expenditures, policies, and programs. Administrators during this time include: Thomas Lynch Montgomery, Actuary and Librarian, 1886-1903; John Rothermel, Director, 1903-1924; and Carl Boyer, Curator, 1924-1928, and Director, 1928-1945.

scopecontent.p: These records detail the financial, administrative, and program aspects of the Wagner Free Institute of Science and the William Wagner estate from 1858 to 1938, with the bulk of the records dating from 1885 to 1924. The records appear to be from three administrators: Thomas Lynch Montgomery, John Rothermel, and Samuel Wagner, President of Wagner Free Institute of Science, 1885-1921, and President Emeritus, 1921-1937. Materials in this collection include trustee minutes, correspondence, library and museum reports, records relating to the building and grounds, receipts, bank books, canceled checks, and rental documents.
